pulls.title: Cleanup pass over the spec draft
pulls.author: cathieyun
pulls.body:
Documentation / spec updates:
- Removed Hash from ciphersuite dependency
- Added explanation of why we are using KVAC instead of BBS
- Clarified that the issuance protocol uses Pedersen commitments, for perfect privacy
- Corrected the incorrect presentation proof scalar descriptions

Behavioral changes:
- Changed the presentationState definition to generate the nonce only when needed (instead of proactively generating / holding onto a presentationNonce). Updated the proof of concept accordingly.
- Changed the proof of concept presentationState to have nonces start at 0 (instead of 1)
-  Tightened the presentation limit bounds to 0 <= nonce < rateLimit (was previously allowing for nonce = rateLimit)

Fixes:
- Added `x2` to the ServerKey test vectors (previously had a typo, repeated `x1` twice).

Some things I have questions about:
- Why aren't the presentation proof statements (5.4) rendering correctly? I don't see anything that should result in a formatting error, but the markdown seems unhappy with the Tag definition.

comments.body:
```suggestion
The BBS anonymous credential scheme, as detailed in {{BBS}} and its variants, is efficient and publicly verifiable, but requires pairings for verification. This is problematic for adoption because pairings are not supported as widely in software and hardware as non-pairing elliptic curves.
```

```suggestion
It is possible to construct a keyed-verification variant of BBS which doesn't use pairings, as discussed in {{BBDT17}} and {{REVISITING_KVAC}}. However these keyed-verification BBS variants require more analysis, proofs of security properties, and review to be considered mature enough for safe deployment.
```

pulls.title: Add Privacy Pass integration draft
pulls.author: chris-wood
pulls.body:
Questions:
1. Should requestContext be the entire challenge, or just issuer name? I think just the issuer name, letting the server use the rest of the TokenChallenge as the presentationContext.
2. Do we need to include the rate limit as a challenge extension? (I think so)
3. How should we encode nonce on the wire? I think 32 bits is probably fine? This does impose an upper bound on the actual rate limit, of course.
4. What do we need in security considerations for the Privacy Pass draft?

comments.author: cathieyun
comments.body:
1. I think that the requestContext should be as minimal as possible. So if we can have it just be the issuer name, that would be ideal (allows for more flexibility upon presentation).
2. By "challenge extension" you mean another field in the TokenChallenge sent from the Client Origin? I had been thinking that the rate limit gets sent with the server public keys - so that can be in the TokenChallenge itself, or alongside it.
   - Though looking through the origin-provided inputs, I see that the Privacy Pass spec has the origin sending the Public Key ID (issuer_key_id), instead of the public key itself. Since the client needs the full public key for the FinalizeCredential call, when does it receive the full public key? Or is this step considered to be out-of-band and not defined by the spec?
3. I think 32 bits is fine.

pulls.title: Add privacy pass security considerations
pulls.author: cathieyun
pulls.body:
Added some security considerations to the privacy pass section, working off of other specs:

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-privacypass-architecture-16#section-6
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-privacypass-public-metadata-issuance/
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc9497/

Some of this repeats the security considerations in the ARC CFRG spec (eg Client Issuance Unlinkability), I'm not sure if it's okay to repeat across both specs, or where they would belong best.

pulls.title: Collapse security considerations
pulls.author: chris-wood
pulls.body: We defined a lot of these things in the architecture document, so I just used that language. Also, I fixed two things: (1) we don't send "presentations," we send "tokens", and (2) the presentation context is the token challenge (and some other stuff); it's not some agreed-upon value between client and origin/issuer.

comments.author: cathieyun
comments.body: LGTM! Thanks for cleaning up the wording, I wasn't sure about some of the terminology.

pulls.title: Reference implementation / test vector updates
pulls.author: cathieyun
pulls.body:
Small changes and cleanups I came across while working on interoperability for the test vectors - mostly domain separator updates. I also removed some unnecessary fields from the Presentation (generatorT, U_prime) and added presentation_context. 

IMO the test vectors should have presentation_context, for presentation creation. I see that generatorT is included currently, which can be a proxy for presentation_context, but it seems better to use presentation_context directly (it also is a bit weird to make the ARC implementation take in a generatorT from a test vector, during presentation creation), so I removed it.

comments.author: cathieyun
comments.body:
Ok, I'm happy to keep the labels in line with the spec (so as not to change the spec).

But even then, we'll need a few tweaks here and there in the poc, like capitalizing "tag" in `generator_T = hash_to_group(self.presentation_context, to_bytes("tag"))` to get them in sync.

comments.author: cathieyun
comments.body:
The reference implementation is now in line with the spec, from what I can tell. I didn't change the spec itself.
And I updated the presentation context encoding to hex. 
PTAL :)

reviews.author: chris-wood
reviews.body: The label changes don't match the spec. Can we please keep them as-is?

comments.body: This should be in hex like the other test vectors.

This doesn't match the spec:

```
  generatorT = G.HashToGroup(presentationContext, "Tag")
```

pulls.title: Cleanup tasks
pulls.author: cathieyun
pulls.body:
Cleanup / documentation tasks:
- Some proof documentation was incorrect - specifically, the comments for statements 5a and 5b in the response proof were in the wrong order. 
- Added request_context to the test vectors, so we can test that request_context gets hashed correctly to become m2. 

Potential additional tasks: 
- Currently, the ProofParticipant initializer ignores the input label, instead setting it to an empty string. We should actually use the label, to differentiate different proofs. However, I didn't make that change in this PR because it changes all the proof test vectors, which would be quite disruptive. Maybe this fix can get rolled into the next change the significantly alters the test vectors.
